utterances: The light bulb moment: I was sitting in this movie theater watching Spellbound, that incredible movie documentary of the kids that are going through the Scripps-Howard Spelling Bee.
I was just like, why don't adults do this anymore?
Why did we - why is this not fun anymore?
And so the Williamsburg Bee was born, where currently the prizes include $40 worth of free drinks and a sandwich.
The bee draws all kinds - some people just out for fun, a few looking to avenge spelling bee losses from childhood and some people who can really spell, like Carolyn.
Ms. CAROLYN D'AQUILA (Social Worker): Carolyn D'Aquila.
D'Aquila?
Ms.
D'AQUILA: D'Aquila - D, apostrophe, A-Q-U-I-L-A.
So my spelling skills started very early.
(Soundbite of laughter)
D'Aquila went to the National Spelling Bee in the 90s and was a pronouncer at the New Hampshire State Spelling Bee for years.
Recently, she became a social worker, which she says, so far, isn't paying for a lot of nights out.
Ms. D'AQUILA: Right.
And there's a recession on and I just got out of school and I don't have a job.
So...
So she started coming to Williamsburg, where she's won several of the recent bees and lots of free drinks.
You're kind of a ringer.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Ms.
D'AQUILA: It's not fair, but I never have to pay for my drinks here.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Williamsburg Spelling Bee co-host Jen Dziura says regulars like D'Aquila make the contest a combination of just-for-fun and real competition.
Actor Daniel Craig is used to becoming iconic characters.
In 2006, he famously shook up the 007 franchise as a new, blond James Bond.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOVIE, ""CASINO ROYALE"")
Well, I think so.
I mean, investments are a function of price; they're a function of risk and return.
And to the extent that the return was improved by higher yields, PIMCO would be attracted, I think, by a 50 basis point or a half a percent higher yield on a 10-year Treasury, now about 3 percent.
If they went up to 3 and a half percent, then a double-A type of nation such as the United States, in our opinion, would be an attractive investment at those yields.
So at this point, as you say, as long as the U.S.
is getting away with a rating that you think we really don't deserve, treasuries aren't attractive.
But if the U.S.
actually manages to blow through the debt ceiling, that's a different story.
The treasuries might be more attractive at 3 percent.
These are countries - what we call, having cleaner dirty shirts.
You know, many sovereign nations around the world basically have debt problems, but there are some with fewer problems than others.
And countries such as Canada and Australia, Germany as well, you know, offer more attractive yields in a cleaner dirty shirt.
Mr.
Gross, how do you explain to people the apparent indifference so far of the markets to the fairly obvious political disarray in Washington over the debt?
Well, I would agree with you in terms of the equity markets - stable since last Friday, when the alarm was sounded by President Obama.
The bond markets as well, relatively stable in terms of their yields.
But I would point out that the dollar itself, which is a fundamental reflection of the credit worthiness of the United States, is at its lowest trade-weighted floor for the past 15 years.
And commodities such as gold and oil and other hard commodities, which are a reflection of a weaker dollar, are doing just that; they're going up in price.

But you're saying that the investor who looks at his or her holdings and says, well, I seem to have about the same number of dollars, or a little bit more, in my portfolio of stocks, and the same number in my bonds - might be accurate.
But if each of those dollars is worth less today than it was a few months ago, it's taken a hit.
Well, that's certainly the case.
That's one of the problems in the United States.

We're not a currency savvy nation, like nations in euro land are because their history, of course, is one in which they were forced to cross borders to make transactions; and there were a multitude of currencies.
And I think Americans need to take a course, in terms of the valuation of the dollar and how it affects their purchasing power, as you pointed out.
Bill Gross, thank you very much for talking with us once again.
Thank you, Robert.
Nice to be here.
Bill Gross, the founder of PIMCO, the big bond investor, spoke to us from Newport Beach, California.
Lawmakers in New York state find themselves in the familiar position.
They're entering the final hours of the legislative session with some major business still unresolved.
One those outstanding issues is a cap on property taxes.
NPR's Joel Rose explains why the New York state legislature is having such a hard time finding common ground.
From Brooklyn to Buffalo, there's one thing all New Yorkers seem to agree on: living in a state is expensive, too expensive.
In case you'd forgotten, this is the state that gave the world the Jimmy McMillan of The Rent Is Too Damn High Party.
There's nowhere to go.
Once again, why?
You said it - the rent is too damn high.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Macmillan wasn't much of a factor in last year's gubernatorial election.
But the man who won, Governor Andrew Cuomo, is taking housing costs seriously.
Cuomo made property tax reform one of the centerpieces of his first year agenda.
And a few weeks ago, the Democratic governor announced a tentative deal to cap local property tax hikes in the state at two percent.
This agreement is a big deal.
I can't tell you how many times someone has come up to me and said: You have to do something about property taxes - I just can't afford to stay in my home anymore.
Today, we're saying we have an agreement to finally do something about it.
The agreement hinges on a classic New York political deal, which is to say a compromise between upstate and New York City.
Suburban and rural interests get property tax reform, while city lawmakers get an extension of rent control laws.
Without those laws rents would skyrocket for hundreds of thousands of low and moderate income New Yorkers.
And with rent control laws set to expire tomorrow, the compromise shows signs of fraying.
State senator Bill Perkins from Harlem and other Democrats want to expand rent control.
We're pushing for more.
We will not be satisfied with just an extension.
We are hopeful that the governor will step up to the plate and give us the kind of strong rent law that protects New Yorkers.
Without strong rent control, New York City lawmakers say they will not support the governor's cap on local property taxes.
Polls show that the tax cap is popular with more than a third of New Yorkers saying it's the most important item on the legislative agenda this session, ahead of ethics reform or same-sex marriage.
But opponents of the cap say those numbers can be misleading.
People don't understand that the negative consequence this will have on the quality of their schools.
And the more that people hear about it the less popular it gets.
Billy Easton directs the Alliance for Quality Education.
He says wealthy school districts in New York already outspend poor districts by a margin of two-to-one.
He's afraid the tax cap will lead to even fewer teachers and resources for the poorest school districts in the state.
That also worries Mark Mishler(ph), a parent who sent two kids to public schools in Albany.
The state is trying to say that we expect you to close the achievement gap, but we're not going to give you the resources to do that.
And were also going to tell you, you can't raise the resources in other ways.
And they're really creating a no-win situation.
One potential winner in the tax cap debate is the business community.
Heather Bricetti, with the Business Council of New York State, says the proposed cap would help companies stay competitive with those in other states.
(Singing in Spanish) Consuelo de los que sufren, Adoracion de la gente...
This month a new off-Broadway play opens, and it celebrates, of all things, the high school mathlete.
You know, the high school mathletes?
You have a math team in your school?
Well, this play asks the question: Can a popular girl who knows Pi to 53 decimal places, can she be on a math team and still be popular?
Well, you can if you're ""Victoria Martin: The Math Team Queen."" That's the title of the play, and it's opening this weekend at the Julia Miles Theater here in New York.
And joining me now to talk more about it is the playwright.
Kathryn Walat is the author of ""Victoria Martin: The Math - Victoria Martin: Math Team Queen."" There's a colon there.
Thanks for talking with us today.
Hi, Ira.
Congratulations...
Thank you.
...on the opening of your play.
Give us a little synopsis of what the play is about.

Well, the play, as you said, the play has to do with the high school math team and Victoria Martin, who is the third most popular sophomore at the high school and who unwittingly finds herself on the team, only to discover that she is great at it and really carries the team and actually changes everyone, all the other kids that are on the team, too.
